185241602.review: An incredibly charming game that took the idea of a "cozy game" and interpreted it a bit too literally. The game is entirely built around burning random household objects (and not so normal household objects) in a fireplace, and can be surprisingly hypnotizing for a few hours whenever you come back to it. I highly recommend it, but the one thing I do find rather annoying is that there is a bit of awkward pacing issues since it takes time for items to arrive in your inventory, and speeding this up uses up a relatively-common currency that can be eaten away at super quickly. Still, the game is very fun and always a joy to come back to from time to time.

🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥了🔥[/h1]
总评【9.5/20】：差强人意
[h3] 尽管评分不高，《小小炼狱》绝对是一部非常优秀的游戏作品。这种优秀，来自玩家游玩《小小炼狱》时的异样体验。[/h3]
主旨构思【3/5】：[b] 荒谬 [/b]。
毫无疑问，《小小炼狱》不论是设定还是主旨都相当荒谬。一场永不停歇的暴风雪，一台要靠烧各种古怪的小物件才能维持火焰的壁炉，一场毁掉一切的大火灾。如果说这款游戏的剧本由精神病人创作，我也不会奇怪。
这场暴雪是什么呢，外界环境的桎梏吗？主视角所在房间代表内心的枷锁？壁炉里被焚烧一遍又一遍的物件，是生活中的麻醉剂吗？这些回答算是一份合格的答卷，但跟标准答案毫不沾边。
和许久前风靡台式机的《粘粘世界》类似，《小小炼狱》的故事深邃而幽暗。玩家能感知到其中存在些什么，但却无法看破。我曾在某个报道里读到，2D BOYs在采访中表示《粘粘世界》的主旨是环境保护。这当然说得通，但游戏内种种细节告诉你远不止此。续作《粘粘世界2》对时间，“风格”的讨论则更加幻妙。作为身处表层的玩家，游戏中各种元素和剧情的堆砌看似和谐且符合逻辑。但，我对它们的内在关联毫无头绪。或许，这款游戏的标答并不存在。
大概是我理解能力不足，终究是悟不透她的主旨。游戏的整体构思也很普通。于是怎么给分便成了个难题，上下限差距可以很大。3分，就3分吧。
叙事表达【2/5】：游戏机制和故事推进结合得很不错，但要说其中讲了个啥，又好像啥都没讲。细节处理上整体还行，烧掉的不少东西都在后期有彩蛋。然而也有些细节处理得比较疑惑，例如为何我出门后没见到被烧毁的糖珠儿家？游戏节奏把握得很恰当，没有让玩家感觉烧东西很浪费时间。整体值得一个“普通”的分数。
游戏玩法【1.5/5】：烧就完事了，你还想要啥？烧烧烧烧烧烧烧烧......
艺术设计【3/5】：音乐加分，烧不同东西时的特效加分。明日公司的画风还是一如既往的“颇具特色”，但看习惯了感觉不错。或许正是这种微妙的风格，才能贴合第一部分中提到的深邃主旨。

184874551.review:
Puntaje: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5)

Un juego para relajarte... hasta que decides completarlo al 100%.

Little Inferno es una experiencia única que combina creatividad, narrativa y una atmósfera peculiarmente acogedora. Es ideal para quienes buscan un juego diferente, alejado de la acción frenética o los desafíos intensos.

Pros:
-Estilo visual encantador: Los gráficos son minimalistas pero cautivadores.
-Banda sonora relajante: La música complementa perfectamente la experiencia.
-Historia intrigante: Aunque el juego parece simple al principio, tiene una narrativa sorprendente.
-Jugabilidad relajante: Encender fuego y experimentar es increíblemente satisfactorio y desestresante.
-Duración accesible: Es un juego corto, perfecto para sesiones rápidas.

Contras:
-Repetitivo a largo plazo: Una vez que descubres la mecánica principal, puede volverse monótono.
-Frustración para los completistas: Buscar todos los combos y logros puede ser un desafío.
-Falta de rejugabilidad: Aunque la experiencia inicial es encantadora, el juego no ofrece mucho contenido para quienes lo terminan rápidamente.

184592167.review:
On the surface, Little Inferno seems almost absurdly simple: a game about burning things in a fireplace. But look deeper, and you’ll find a haunting meditation on consumerism, loneliness, and the ways we seek meaning in a world that often feels cold and indifferent. Beneath the playful exterior lies a work of quiet brilliance—a game that doesn’t just ask you to light a fire but to question why we’re drawn to the flame in the first place.

In Little Inferno, you’re given a fireplace, a catalog, and a task: burn things. Toys, photographs, food, memories—it all goes up in flames, rewarding you with coins to purchase more items to burn. On paper, it’s a game loop that seems shallow, but in execution, it becomes an almost hypnotic ritual. You’re not just burning objects; you’re burning ideas, dreams, and fragments of a world you’ll never fully see.

The setting is a dystopia hidden in plain sight. The world outside your fireplace is cold, gray, and uninhabitable. All you have for warmth and companionship is the flame and the occasional letters from a mysterious neighbor, Sugar Plumps, whose gleeful yet tragic musings add a layer of humanity to this bleak existence. Through her, and through the bizarre catalog of burnable items, you begin to realize that this isn’t just a game about burning things—it’s a game about what we choose to keep, what we let go of, and what’s left when the fire dies.

Fire has always been a symbol of transformation, both destructive and purifying. In Little Inferno, every object you burn serves as a reminder of life’s impermanence. A family portrait crumbles to ash. A stuffed animal erupts in flames. Even objects that seem nonsensical—a jar of fireflies, a miniature cityscape, a singing fish—carry a weight when you watch them vanish.

But the game doesn’t let you simply observe. It makes you complicit. You burn for warmth, for coins, for progress. You burn because there’s nothing else to do. And in doing so, you confront the futility of it all. Each new catalog item promises novelty, but the thrill fades quickly, leaving you searching for the next thing to ignite. It’s a cycle that mirrors consumerism’s empty promises: buy, use, discard, repeat. What are we really chasing? What do we hope to find at the bottom of the ash?

As you burn through your catalogs, letters from Sugar Plumps arrive with increasing frequency. At first, her messages seem lighthearted, almost nonsensical. But as the game progresses, her tone shifts. She begins to question the world outside, her own choices, and even the act of burning itself. Through her, the game gently explores themes of loneliness and connection. In a world where human contact is fleeting and indirect, Sugar Plumps becomes a lifeline—a reminder that even in isolation, we crave understanding.

There’s a quiet tragedy in Sugar Plumps’ journey, one that mirrors your own. Like you, she’s trying to find warmth in a world that offers little solace. But unlike you, she dares to imagine something beyond the fireplace. Her letters challenge you to look past the flame and consider what lies outside the constraints of this small, burning box.

Little Inferno isn’t just a game—it’s a mirror. It forces you to confront the ways we fill our lives with distractions, consuming endlessly to avoid the uncomfortable truths we’d rather not face. The fireplace is a microcosm of modern existence: an endless stream of things to occupy our attention, none of which truly satisfy. And yet, we keep burning.

But the game doesn’t judge you for this. It understands that the fire is comforting, that sometimes we need the distraction, the warmth, the light. What it asks, however, is whether we’re willing to look beyond the fire when the time comes. Will we continue to burn, or will we step outside and face the cold?

Without spoiling too much, the conclusion of Little Inferno takes a sharp turn, pulling you out of the fireplace and into the world beyond. It’s a jarring but profoundly necessary moment. For hours, you’ve been confined to the small, cozy space of the flame, lulled into a sense of security by its warmth. The ending asks you to leave that comfort behind and confront the unknown.

This final act is a beautiful metaphor for growth. It’s easy to stay by the fire, to cling to what’s familiar and safe. But true meaning lies in stepping out into the unknown, embracing the uncertainty and coldness of the world in search of something greater. The game’s ending is both hopeful and melancholic—a reminder that growth often requires leaving behind what we once thought we couldn’t live without.

The art style of Little Inferno is deceptively childlike, with its bright colors and whimsical designs. But there’s an underlying sadness to its aesthetic, a sense that this is a world frozen in time, caught between decay and nostalgia. The crackling of the fire, the cheerful jingles of the catalogs, and the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack all work together to create an atmosphere that’s both cozy and unsettling.

Little Inferno is a game that lingers. Long after the flames have died and the screen has faded to black, its questions remain: What are we burning for? What do we hope to find in the ashes? And most importantly, are we ready to step away from the fire and face the cold, uncertain world beyond?

This is not a game for everyone. Its slow pace, minimalist mechanics, and abstract storytelling may frustrate players looking for traditional gameplay. But for those willing to engage with its deeper themes, Little Inferno offers an experience that is as thought-provoking as it is unique.

In the end, Little Inferno isn’t just about burning things—it’s about burning away illusions, fears, and the boundaries we place around ourselves. It’s about finding meaning in a world that often feels meaningless. And most of all, it’s about the courage to leave the fire behind and step into the unknown.

Final Rating: 10/10
A philosophical journey disguised as a playful, absurd little game.

184431083.review:
PLUSY:
+ grafika w stylu Tima Burtona
+ historyjka, którą można rozumieć jako przestrogę przed uzależnieniami
+ fajny klimat
+ bardzo fajna fizyka spalanych przedmiotów
+ różne efekty palonych rzeczy

MINUSY:
- szybko zaczyna nużyć, a rozgrywka staje się powtarzalna. Bardziej przypomina grę mobilną
- płytka rozgrywka, która polega jedynie na kupowaniu przedmiotów i wrzucaniu ich do kominka
- cooldown, szczególnie na dalszych etapach gry czekanie po 5 minut staje się faktem (gdy skończą się kupony skracające czas oczekiwania)
- można robić kombosy przez kombinacje spalania kilku rzeczy, ale trzeba je odgadnąć po nazwie kombosa (co czasami jest trudne) lub poprzez wielokrotne próby spalania różnych rzeczy. To w połączeniu z cooldownem i oczekiwaniem na spalenie wszystkiego jest nieco monotonne. Na szczęście są solucje ...
- propagowanie piromani, a także krzywdzenia żywych futrzaków wśród dzieci. Komentarze twórców w tym względzie nic nie zmieniają
- zmarnowany potencjał

9.5/10 - Could be longer, hope we get more instalments in the same world.

184158766.review: Um dos meus jogos favoritos de quando eu era criança, assistia Alanzoka e componhia mais jogando isso era muito divertido na época, principalmente por ter uma história mais voltado para criança e 12 anos depois do seu lançamento ainda é divertido, mesmo tendo crianças gritando e morrendo sendo queimadas em uma lareira para um sádico rir, e isso acontece no mínimo 3 vezes (Little Inferno 1 x GTA 0)

184099318.review: Игра отличная, но недавно я столкнулся с проблемой. Когда я запускаю игру, видеокарта нагружается на 90 процентов. Видеокарта для такой игры не слабая: gtx 1660 ti. Игру переустанавливал, целостность файлов проверял, пробовал запускать с ДЛЦ и без. Ничего не помогает. Интересно, один ли я столкнулся с такой проблемой или нет. Если у кого-то тоже такое было, прошу помочь. (я уже начинаю задумываться, что нагрузка видеокарты - это специальная задумка разрабов, чтобы создать ощущение, будто ты сидишь перед печкой, хдд)

184043329.review: Little Inferno is a quirky and enjoyable game that blends dark humor with creative gameplay. The concept of burning various objects in a fireplace is simple yet strangely satisfying, and the game’s unique art style adds to its charm. As you progress, the story unfolds in unexpected ways.

183657342.review: After all these years it is still a super cozy game (sometimes a little creepy). Perfect game to play during christmas or cold weather of the year.

183656613.review:
Its a great game filled with love, its the type of game that everyone should play at least once, its that great!

This was actually my second playthrough of the game, i pirated this game like 10 years ago because i literally didnt know where to get it otherwise, and back then it already got me emotional, buying it now and playing it again and yep, still just as emotional as back then.

The gameplay is fun and relaxed, the story is great, the music is even better.

Buy it!

183627836.review:
Hands down, By all means, one of the Best Indie games probably ever created.
Its sad to see this great game not being talked about in most modern times, as it has it all. Every line of Fuggin CODE within this game oozes love and care.
Likable Characters, Great story with an Excellent Message, Amazing Art style, Fun (Yet sometimes Repetitive) gameplay, and the best Soundtrack i have ever heard in a game. Period. This game has some of the greatest music i've heard in gaming. The fact that the soundtrack is FREE is CRIMINAL.
Kyle Gabler, Give me more music you beautiful bastard.

183603263.review:
Soğuk giderek daha da soğuk olacak olan dünyada sadece şöminesi ve şöminede yakmak için alacağımız eşyaları seçmemizi sağlayacak olan kataloğu olan bir çocuğuz
hava o kadar soğuk ki şöminenin başında oturmaktan ve daha çok ürün satın alıp daha çok şey yakmaktan başka yapılacak hiçbir şey yok bu dünyada
Küçükken oynadığımı hatırlıyorum o zamanlar bile etkilemişti beni neden etkilediğini yıllar sonra aklıma düşüp satın alıp tekrar oynadığımda anladım belki nostaji hissiyle bu kadar sevdim ama bir şans vermenizi isterim

183575694.review: Burning things for money is really fun.

183569897.review: 一定！记得！不要！烧掉！抱抱券！

183567497.review:
Eu tive muito fator replay nesse jogo e constantemente estou voltando. A história, macabra e ao mesmo tempo engraçada com uma crítica forte à questões ambientais, o gameplay que é simples mas tão rico e funcional, os puzzles que no geral são super simples mas divertidos. A trilha sonora e os efeitos sonoros que são impecáveis numa estética bizarra-fofa.

Minha única crítica desfavorável é que ele é curto DEMAIS e nunca vai ter sequência por ser 'flopado'.

Fora né o preço que subiu. Certamente vale seus 20 conto nele.

183561346.review: Bля буду супер игра с невероятным сюжетом. Подходит чтоб поиграть со своими отпрысками. МБ это лучше чем СВ0

183539521.review: Who doesn't love to pointlessly burn things? Alright, maybe normal people, but being normal is overrated. Burn it all down.

183532189.review: A Christmas tradition at this point, I played this game every Christmas even before the Christmas update they added last year. Can't wait for the remaster that's coming soon! Would wholely recommend this combotastic game!

183529448.review: The perfect game for the Christmas season.  A festive game where you get coins for burning things in creative combinations.  Not all of them though, the Generations Combo was rather vague, no shame in looking up the answer for that one.  And it has this underlying story that brims more and more as you go on.  So this Christmas, sit back, grab a pint of egg nog, and watch chestnuts, banks, cursed idols, incriminating documents, and pooping casts roast on an open fire.  (by the way, you can actually burn jpgs and pngs in your pictures folder in game.  Now you can finally burn that picture of your ex-girlfriend Charlene who left you for Joaquin with the puka-shell necklace and get the closure you desire).

183516988.review: The definition of a 7/10 game. It knows what it is cosy but pointless and that's ok.

183503699.review: Krásná relaxující hra s krátkým příběhem cca na 3 hodinky. Hra ve které jen kupujete hračky a pak je spalujete aby vás zahřály. Pokud si chcete odpočinout tak tohle je hra kterou si zahrát.
